texts.definition: Game Items that differ from other game items solely based on their cosmetic characteristics.
markups: <style="Definition">Game Items that differ from other game items solely based on their cosmetic characteristics.</style>

When players have the possibility to create characters in games, and the surroundings they inhabit, they often wish to beautify or distinguish these in various ways. While this may be achieved to a certain degree by choosing any game items to wear or furnish that looks different from others,  <style="CurrentLink">Cosmetic Game Items</style> provide an extra level of this by providing variety for the same type of functional game items, or by providing extra game items that exist only for this purpose.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style> lets players personalize their sims' appearances to a high degree, including giving them clothing and jewelry. These do not provide any system benefits but provide players with a wide range of possibilities. While all furniture in the games do provide benefits or the possibilities of performing actions, tiles and wallpaper do not even if they vary in price depending on their appearance.

Entering body shops in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Grand%20Theft%20Auto%20series">Grand Theft Auto series</link></style> to change colors of one's car is not only done to escape the attention of the legal authorities; it can simple be because one wants a new color. Players that complete 100% of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Grand%20Theft%20Auto:%20Vice%20City">Grand Theft Auto: Vice City</link></style> are rewarded with a t-shirt saying "I JUST COMPLETED GRAND THEFT AUTO: VICE CITY AND ALL I GOT IS THIS LOUSY T-SHIRT".

Shirts and tabards worn in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> do not affect gameplay but only the appearance of the characters that wear them. Many of the game items in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Entropia%20Universe">Entropia Universe</link></style> likewise do not have to have any gameplay value but can still be sought after items in trading.

Players of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ravenwood%20Fair">Ravenwood Fair</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zombie%20Lane">Zombie Lane</link></style> can purchase both clothing and ornaments that have no direct gameplay effect, except possibly that the ornaments take up space. Several of the items created in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style>, e.g. paintings and books, have no practical value except enable players to create the appearance of various items found in the real world.

Creating <style="CurrentLink">Cosmetic Game Items</style> consist of choosing <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> and then deciding on its visual appearance. Two main groups of <style="CurrentLink">Cosmetic Game Items</style> are ornaments and those that are <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>. Ornaments, found for example in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ravenwood%20Fair">Ravenwood Fair</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style>, are <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> that exist in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> for the only purpose of decoration, and maybe to be <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>. Those that are <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> are used to change the appearance of <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>.

The value of <style="CurrentLink">Cosmetic Game Items</style> can be increased by making it a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resource</link></style>; the t-shirt <style="Link"><link="achievements">Achievements</link></style> for completing 100% of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Grand%20Theft%20Auto:%20Vice%20City">Grand Theft Auto: Vice City</link></style> or killing 10000 zombies in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zombie%20Lane">Zombie Lane</link></style> are examples of this.

<style="CurrentLink">Cosmetic Game Items</style> may seem to be a purely <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Diegetic%20Patterns">Diegetic Pattern</link></style> but since these <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> are chosen by players for their appearance they are likely to have a significance outside the game as well.

<style="CurrentLink">Cosmetic Game Items</style> are a way to modulate <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> with other purposes, and a way to instantiate those that only have cosmetic value. They can provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> and if they are a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resource</link></style>, e.g. by only being given as part of <style="Link"><link="achievements">Achievements</link></style>, also convey a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game-Based%20Social%20Statuses">Game-Based Social Statuses</link></style>. Those that change the appearance of <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> by being <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> let players engage in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Avatar%20Personalization">Avatar Personalization</link></style>. This can support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Coordination">Coordination</link></style> in games where players have <style="Link"><link="functional-roles">Functional Roles</link></style>.

They can on their own merits lead to both in-game <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="game-element-trading">Game Element Trading</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. In fact, since the cosmetic aspect of a <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Item</link></style> does not directly affect gameplay, the pattern can be said to mainly be used to give <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style>.
